turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: At least it did when I was in school.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But... but they call it...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And... and when it does, they call it a service.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What about that answer?
What about that hypothetical?

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: Your Honor, let me just speak...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And I might say also there's a greater danger that the student will be identified as associated with the views of the school paper than when you got an indirect thing like this.

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: That's about three hypos in one here, Your Honor, that... Justice Stevens, that... I would say it this way.
There's no Abood complaint against non-speech activities.
So, I think the athletic stuff would be fine.
If... if there's... there's no...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's the easy part.

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The newspaper is the hard part.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: The Abood case... there's no Abood claim for government speech.
The newspapers may fall into that, the student newspapers, if it's the official university one.
We don't have that case here, and I... I know that all the lower courts have resolved it the other way.
And the third thing... I don't recall, Justice Stevens... was?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it's... it's captured by a group with which the person who has to pay the activity fee violently disagrees, particularly because it's the University of Chicago Daily Maroon that's associated with all students of the University of Chicago.
Of course, that's not a State...

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: I think that if there were... I do not know the answer to it because I think there's a government speech issue.
If you have Rosenberger's newspaper, I think people could object to funding its Christian proselytizing.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But we were talking here about a university newspaper.
Isn't the argument available that this is one of the instructional devices at the university...

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: and that it should take particular views is... is no more extraordinary than that you should have a communist professor?

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which also happens.

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: That's right, Justice Scalia, yes.
That's right, Your Honor.
In conclusion, the Seventh Circuit correctly ruled that the University of Wisconsin's mandatory fee system violates the Abood and Keller rights of the students.
The university may have an educational mission, but it has a greater First Amendment duty to protect and recognize the right of conscience of each individual student.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If you allowed opt-out as... as Abood, and then you have students that don't opt out, so you still have a fund...

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Could the students who opt out then make a demand for viewpoint-neutral funds?

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: If the... if the funds were...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You're a Wobbly.
You... you opt out and so your funds aren't used.
Can they then demand that the funds that are used still be used on a viewpoint-neutral basis?

turn.speaker: jordan_w_lorence
turn.label: Mr. Jordan W. Lorence
turn.text: There might be a free rider question there, Your Honor.
I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Lorence.
Ms. Ullman, you have 1 minute remaining.

turn.speaker: susan_k_ullman
turn.label: Ms. Susan K. Ullman
turn.text: Setting aside WISPIRG, the other groups that were funded through GSS were services and there's no claim that there was any viewpoint discrimination there.
The University of Wisconsin...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You mean really services.

turn.speaker: susan_k_ullman
turn.label: Ms. Susan K. Ullman
turn.text: Yes.
The University of Wisconsin has determined that it is important to facilitate the speech of diverse groups, that this furthers the university's educational mission and First Amendment values.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Ullman.
The case is submitted.
